questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT -
You have a Microsoft 365 E5 subscription that contains two users named Admin1 and Admin2.
All users are assigned a Microsoft 365 Enterprise E5 license and auditing is turned on.
You create the audit retention policy shown in the exhibit. (Click the Exhibit tab.)
//IMG//

After Policy1 is created, the following actions are performed:
✑ Admin1 creates a user named User1.
✑ Admin2 creates a user named User2.
How long will the audit events for the creation of User1 and User2 be retained? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Hot Area:
//IMG//

discussion.content:
Admin 1 who created user 1 has the policy applied which indicates only keep the audit log for 90 days.

Admin 2 who created user 2 does not have a policy applied. Since all users are assigned an E5 license then the audit log will be kept for 1 year

"To retain an audit log for longer than 90 days (and up to 1 year), the user who generates the audit log (by performing an audited activity) must be assigned an Office 365 E5 or Microsoft 365 E5 license or have a Microsoft 365 E5 Compliance or E5 eDiscovery and Audit add-on license."

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/compliance/audit-log-retention-policies?view=o365-worldwide
On test taken 5.10.21
6 months both

comments.content: But Admin1 is taking the action to create User1. Therefore the custom policy applies to the action because Admin1 took the action. So the 90 days thing would apply to that one.

discussion.content: I think this should be 365 for both User1 and User2 as all users are E5 and neither User1 nor User2 are referenced in the policy with 90 days(that is Admin1 only).
I was confused about this b/c E5 audits are kept for 1 year but then I saw Nunununu's explanation and it makes sense. With that said, Answers are correct.

All custom audit log retention policies (created by your organization) take priority over the default retention policy. For example, if you create an audit log retention policy for Exchange mailbox activity that has a retention period that's shorter than one year, audit records for Exchange mailbox activities will be retained for the shorter duration specified by the custom policy.
Answer is correct. You do not configure any alerts from SP admin center.

comments.content: Yes, it can but only to yourself and here the question is send to HR.

SPO can send alerts regarding changes to documents:
https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/office/create-an-alert-to-get-notified-when-a-file-or-folder-changes-in-sharepoint-e5a79e7b-a146-46da-a9ef-d65409ba8918

discussion.content: Answer is correct
but why cant DLP be applied as well?

comments.content: DLP is more focused on specific types of data, so it will be good answer if we were talking about for example PII or Credit Card Numbers (or other types of data, that were define and include in DLP policy). This question is more concentrating on alerting for every file share, not only specific one (containing specific data)

questions.question_text:
You need to notify the manager of the human resources department when a user in the department shares a file or folder from the department's Microsoft
SharePoint Online site.
What should you do?

choices.C: From the SharePoint Online admin center, modify the sharing settings.
choices.D: From the Security & Compliance admin center, create a data loss prevention (DLP) policy.
choices.A: From the Security & Compliance admin center, create an alert policy.
choices.B: From the SharePoint Online site, create an alert.

yeah given the answer explanation and the reference link, i suspect the question was supposed to be: which users can "purchase", "add" or "assign", not "install". 
I guess we'll never know.

User1 and User2 can purchase.
All users can install.
Misspelled for sure

This question has nothing to do with purchasing app

Answer provided is wrong as every user can install from a private store. "When admins add apps to the private store, all employees in the organization can view and download the apps."
Reference: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-store/distribute-apps-from-your-private-store

User1 and User2 only
User3 and User4 only

...

discussion.content:
Answer is correct

Allow users to shop controls the shopping experience in Microsoft Store for Education. When this setting is on, Purchasers and Basic Purchasers can purchase products and services from Microsoft Store for Education.

Referenced link is correct

comments.content: Topic 3, Question #31 has almost the same wording with and option E for all users objects.
Agree - All users can install - Qu 31 Topic 3 has the full question and answers

discussion.content: User 1 , there is a similar question

questions.answer_description:
Allow users to shop controls the shopping experience in Microsoft Store for Education. When this setting is on, Purchasers and Basic Purchasers can purchase products and services from Microsoft Store for Education.
References:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-store/acquire-apps-microsoft-store-for-business
questions.question_text:
Your company has a Microsoft Azure Active Directory (Azure AD) tenant named contoso.com.
You sign for Microsoft Store for Business.
The tenant contains the users shown in the following table.
//IMG//

Microsoft Store for Business has the following Shopping behavior settings:
✑ Allow users to shop is set to On
✑ Make everyone a Basic Purchaser is set to Off
You need to identify which users can install apps from the Microsoft for Business private store.
Which users should you identify?

You have a Microsoft 365 subscription that contains a Microsoft Azure Active Directory (Azure AD) tenant named contoso.com.
In the tenant, you create a user named User1.
You need to ensure that User1 can publish retention labels from the Microsoft 365 compliance center. The solution must use the principle of least privilege.
To which role group should you add User1?

discussion.content:
Answer is correct. This is a better source: 

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/compliance/get-started-with-retention?view=o365-worldwide

"To grant permissions for this limited administration, we recommend that you add users to the Compliance Administrator admin role group.

Alternatively to using this default role, you can create a new role group and add the Retention Management role to this group. For a read-only role, use View-Only Retention Management.

For instructions to add users to the default roles or create your own role groups, see Permissions "

So, since Retention Manager has less permissions than Compliance Manager, and is included in the "Records Management" role in the compliance center, B is correct.

comments.content: sorry, I mean C: Compliance admin.
records management role consists of retention management too

updated. 
just tested in my tenant. Yes, the answer is correct. giving the user Record Management role in Compliance center allow the user to create retention labels

well, the given answer here is RECORD management, not RETENTION management.

if it was a typo then the answer B was right. otherwise A: Compliance admin :)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/compliance/create-apply-retention-labels?view=o365-worldwide
Records Management role

Compare permissions for Records Management and the Compliance Administrator Role Groups here: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/security/office-365-security/permissions-in-the-security-and-compliance-center?view=o365-worldwide

Clearly B. Records Management

questions.question_text:
You plan to use the Security & Compliance admin center to import several PST files into Microsoft 365 mailboxes.
Which three actions should you perform before you import the data? Each correct answer presents part of the solution.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

discussion.content:
The Answer is Correct: BCF
You have to be assigned the Mailbox Import Export role in Exchange Online to import PST files to Office 365 mailboxes. By default, this role isn't assigned to any role group in Exchange Online. You can add the Mailbox Import Export role to the Organization Management role group. Or you can create a role group, assign the Mailbox Import Export role, and then add yourself as a member.

comments.content: Agree! with SCT. I've been doing this PST Import recently with our clients.

discussion.content:
Here is a good visual reference to clear all doubts. https://youtu.be/8DhOTQPzFyU

A. From the Exchange admin center, create a public folder. (No, you don't need to create public folder.)
B. Copy the PST files by using AzCopy. (Yes, you copy using Azcopy or use app for GUI.)
C. From the Exchange admin center, assign admin roles. (Yes, Mailbox Import Export role is required.)
D. From the Microsoft Azure portal, create a storage account that has a blob container. (No, you don't create. You just copy and use it. It's given.)
E. From the Microsoft 365 admin center, deploy an add-in. (Not related at all.)
F. Create a mapping file that uses the CSV file format. (Yes, you need to map users and pst.)

Selected Answer: BCF
The Answer is Correct: BCF
Answers are correct and VTHAR has best explanation.
BCF - 100% (I just did this task recently)

B. Copy the PST files by using AzCopy.
C. From the Exchange admin center, assign admin roles.
F. Create a mapping file that uses the CSV file format.
Same as MS-100 Topic4-15 https://www.examtopics.com/exams/microsoft/ms-100/view/25/

comments.content:
Correctly. See also also question "What permissions are required to create import jobs in the Office 365 Import Service?"
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/compliance/importing-pst-files-to-office-365?view=o365-worldwide
Agreed, you need permissions to create the job (C), that then gives you the AZ tool and URLS (B), then use mapping file (F)

discussion.content:
I believe it is CBF. Roles must be assigned before being able to access the Import section in security and compliance which is required to download Azcopy. Further, this point is highlighted in the note in step 1. See link

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/compliance/use-network-upload-to-import-pst-files?view=o365-worldwide#step-1-copy-the-sas-url-and-install-azcopy

B. Copy the PST files by using AzCopy.
C. From the Exchange admin center, assign admin roles.
F. Create a mapping file that uses the CSV file format.
selection is BDF

choices.A: From the Exchange admin center, create a public folder.
choices.F: Create a mapping file that uses the CSV file format.
